ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Another note on activation
ygData.msgSnippet: ... Yah, you d need recurrent nodes to time-delay.  I don t understand how this works in the iterative-update, but I would like to, if someone could

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	delsp=yes;
	format=flowed


On Apr 13, 2007, at 7:36 AM, Kenneth Stanley wrote:

> -The order-independent method of activation can utilize a kind
> of "delay chain memory" while in-order activation cannot. A delay

Yah, you'd need recurrent nodes to time-delay.  I don't understand  
how this works in the iterative-update, but I would like to, if  
someone could demonstrate it to me.  What I don't see is how any kind  
of delay can happen in feed forward connections?

Of course a recurrent chain of nodes can indeed work just as well in  
the single update method.

> -A big advantage of order-independent activation is that you don't
> need to know which connections are recurrent and which are not in
> order to activate properly. In fact, you treat all connections
> exactly the same: every connection moves activation from its source

Ok, this I don't understand.  It sounds like you're describing the  
sorted-update activation to me.  :)

In my single update algorithm, I treat all connections and nodes  
exactly the same.  Even better than that, I don't artificially add  
any "memory" (i.e. prior activation variables) to my nodes.  The  
examples posted early demonstrate this.

I appreciate your help in trying to clearly define this.

--Steve
--Apple-Mail-2-603767491
